input: The proposal, unveiled by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority over the summer, would have created some 150 new Internet address categories.  The move was heralded by many for offering relief from the growing crowding of addresses ending in "com," the most popular and enduring designation for private sites.  It was opposed by some trademark holders, who charged the plan would increase their already high costs of protecting their marks on the Internet. Others said it would give the governments of some countries too much control over the Net.

Nonetheless, several trademark owners voiced their opposition, asserting that the implementation of this plan would further augment their already substantial expenses in safeguarding their trademarks online. Additionally, critics argued that it would excessively empower certain nations' governments, granting them excessive control over the Internet.

input: This situation will grow more complicated as worldwide electronic commerce takes off.  International electronic commerce has been particularly difficult to regulate, as legal systems from country to country differ. The United States can create laws applicable domestically, but companies in foreign countries can often ignore them with impunity. However, there are areas where the federal government is trying to take the lead.

Nevertheless, certain domains remain where the federal government aims to assume a leadership role.

input: "The federal government should not jerk the reins on the Internet," said Jeff Richards, a partner at law firm Heller, Ehrman White & McAuliffe in San Francisco, which markets a wide range of legal services for online companies. "But it could set guidelines and provide [state] governments with leeway to [develop] new laws on a case-by-case basis." Nevertheless, some rules are slowing emerging. Earlier this month, President Clinton signed the Telecommunications Act, which restricts online access to minors, streamlines cellular phone industry regulation and helps fund schools' Internet connections. The law outweighs the much debated Communications Decency Act, which was struck down as unconstitutional last summer.  Administrative bodies at the federal and state level have cracked down on certain activities they deem illegal. The Federal Trade Commission has ordered six online marketers to immediately halt a scheme in which "spammers" sneaked advertising onto an unsuspecting user's Web site. Four states have sued online cigarette retailers for disregarding a 1992 law that prohibits shipments of cigarettes and smokeless tobacco items through the mail.

However, there are already some regulations starting to emerge. For instance, President Clinton recently signed the Telecommunications Act, which aims to protect minors online, streamline cellular phone industry regulations, and fund schools' Internet connections. This law takes precedence over the controversial Communications Decency Act, which was deemed unconstitutional. Additionally, federal and state administrative bodies have taken action against certain illegal activities. Furthermore, four states have filed lawsuits against online cigarette retailers for violating a 1992 law that bans the shipment of cigarettes and smokeless tobacco through the mail.

input: The restrictions sought by Congress and other governments here and abroad, could hamper growth of the industry, some experts warn. "We all understand the value of broader consumer protection but we don't want it to come at the expense of our ability to reach new markets," said Wendy Melillo, vice president of business affairs at News2U, an Internet broadcast firm. "We don't want legislation to inhibit our ability to expand their products." The industry is working with Congress to prevent any laws that would unduly restrict online commerce. "We are trying to work out a rational, self-regulatory scheme rather than put something into law," said Mike Godwin, staff counsel for the Electronic Frontier Foundation. "We don't want to have the Congress set up another big, unwieldy bureaucracy to just rubber-stamp what the marketplace is doing." Longstanding labor laws also govern the hiring of independent contractors or outsourced workers. As online firms contract out more work, they should make sure they avoid potential legal problems with unpaid overtime or minimum-wage regulations, said David C. Vladeck, a Washington attorney and professor at the Georgetown University Law Center.

"It is essential that taxpayers comply with the regulations in a timely manner in order for any revenue to be collected," the report said.  The Treasury also believes that the taxation of the Internet should follow regulations designed to apply to all forms of business.  "The taxation of electronic business transactions should recognize that today's electronic business models may drastically reduce the amount of labor and other resources necessary to produce a given product," Robert Davidson, a Treasury official said in a memo to the department.  But while recognizing the special needs of electronic businesses, the Treasury should also be careful not to create loopholes, the report said.  The report proposed that Congress pass uniform laws covering the taxation of income from all sources, and that the department take steps to ensure that current forms of taxation, such as for capital gains and other income not subject to withholding, continue to apply to electronic commerce.  The report acknowledged that changing old laws might prove difficult, and proposed that the department sponsor conferences to discuss taxation issues. The report also proposed that the department create a task force to monitor the issue.

input: The report is especially critical of France, which recently enacted a law that would effectively impose a tax on electronic transmissions. The task force's draft report criticised the policy as an "attempt to regulate the Internet through taxation." The first section of the draft report, titled "Empowering a Free Market for the Global Internet," urged the administration to pursue its war against international regulation of the Internet. It proposed the U.S. government urge other countries to oppose all forms of "discriminatory" regulation, such as taxes or requirements that each country have a physical presence for doing business over the Internet. Taxation should be based on easy-to-apply criteria like the country or state of residence of the consumer, the draft said. The second part of the report urges government assistance for schools and other institutions in the United States to ensure they can buy technology at discount prices. In addition to promoting U.S. technology exports, it also encourages research to better protect the security and privacy of Internet transactions and more research into the effects of the Internet on society and the economy.

input: "We basically heard their frustration," said Commerce Undersecretary William Reinsch. The regulations released Monday reflect the government's intention to let U.S. companies export certain encryption products. But an industry alliance that includes giants such as Microsoft Corp. and Apple Computer Inc. blasted the rules as unworkable and confusing and said Wednesday it is prepared to go to Congress to get changes. "The regulations were so complex and in some cases so illogical that you couldn't actually comply with them."

input: The incident was the latest in a rash of cyber-break-ins into high-profile web sites. On August 23, a hacker rang up $14,000 in electronic bills by manipulating a flaw in the Oracle Corp. web site. Oracle's web site is used by businesses to obtain updates on the company's software products. And on August 27, hackers broke into the Microsoft Corp. web site and replaced its home page with one of their own - an electronic voodoo doll with Microsoft chief executive Bill Gates' face pinned to its back. In each case, the hackers exploited security holes that allowed them to gain access to the web sites' computers.

Additionally, on August 27, hackers successfully breached the Microsoft Corp. website and replaced its homepage with a personalized creation - an electronic voodoo doll featuring the likeness of Microsoft's CEO, Bill Gates, with pins piercing its back. In both instances, the hackers capitalized on security vulnerabilities, exploiting them to gain illicit access to the targeted websites' computer systems.

input: The bill's repeal of Section 32 - which allows certain companies to buy up to 10 percent of a bank's stock - would apply to all entities, including insurance companies. input: Leach's bill would also create a "Universal Charters Act" to create an alternative chartering system that would provide national banking powers to companies within any state. He said it would require the creation of national banking standards, regulatory procedures, agency oversight and consumer protections. The bill would merge the Office of Thrift Supervision into the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and create the Office of Financial Supervision to help coordinate the activities of the Federal Reserve, OTS and OCC. The bill calls for an advisory council be created to give thrift customers a voice in regulators' rulemaking.

As part of this overhaul, the Office of Thrift Supervision would be integrated into the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and a new entity, known as the Office of Financial Supervision, would be introduced to effectively coordinate the efforts of the Federal Reserve, OTS, and OCC. Additionally, the bill emphasizes the significance of engaging the voices of thrift customers in the decision-making process by proposing the establishment of an advisory council dedicated to providing input on regulators' rulemaking.

input: Local phone companies previously argued that people were increasingly bypassing long-distance companies by communicating through the Internet and that they should get access fees as compensation.  But the study released Wednesday found that the total Internet traffic flowing through the phone network was only two percent of domestic long-distance traffic in 1995.  The Internet coalition urged the Federal Communications Commission to impose a $1,500 limit on the connection charges Internet companies pay per month for direct access to the phone network.  The group also recommended that the FCC encourage local phone companies to combine their signalling and voice networks, as AT&T and Nynex Corp. have done, to reduce capacity bottlenecks. AT&T calls its combination SNEAK, or low-rate circuit switching. It essentially splits the switchs into two networks, so that they are not overwhelmed by Internet callers.

The coalition also advised the FCC to encourage local phone companies to merge their signalling and voice networks, following the example set by AT&T and Nynex Corp. input: "The guide does not dictate a single 'model' policy that governments should adopt," said the draft distributed to journalists, which is expected to be approved late this month.  Rather, it is intended to help countries identify the public interests involved, review their own needs, and decide how best to "regulate and promote the use of encryption." In many areas, the draft report stops short of endorsing administration policy. On U.S. efforts to persuade other countries to adopt its key recovery system -- which provides the government with certain access to decode scrambled messages -- the guidelines simply suggest that governments consider such a system.
Revise this with your best effort: "The draft, which is anticipated to receive final approval later this month, clarifies that the guide does not impose a singular 'model' policy for governments to follow," stated the document distributed to journalists. Its primary objective is to assist countries in understanding the public interests at stake, assessing their own requirements, and determining the most effective approach to "regulate and promote the use of encryption." The draft report refrains from fully endorsing administrative policies in various areas. Regarding the United States' endeavors to persuade other nations to adopt its key recovery system, which grants the government limited access to decipher encrypted messages, the guidelines simply suggest that governments take into account the option of implementing such a system.

The OECD has assigned top priority to negotiating encryption policies, with the United States specifically aiming to restrict the exportation of robust encryption technologies without providing a means for government authorities to decipher the code.

input: At their first hearing on the issue, members of the House Banking Committee set out the main elements of pending legislation that would essentially divorce financials from commercial activity. input: Roukema and D'Amato, a fierce and consistent proponent of deregulation, both proposed to broadly expand the list of "financial activities" a firm can engage in while still being eligible for charters from banking regulators. This would include insurance, securities and investment advice, and would allow, for example, an insurance company to partially own and bank and vice versa. D'Amato's bill would permit virtually unlimited new forms of financial combinations, while Roukema's language is more conservative, allowing no more than a 10-percent stake -- and possibly less -- of a non-financial firm in a financial firm. She said her bill "will provide diversity and option to the American financial consumer, but at the same time be mindful of consumer safeguards and competition."

D'Amato's bill, in particular, embraces a more expansive approach, essentially allowing unlimited new forms of financial combinations. On the other hand, Roukema's bill takes a more cautious stance by permitting no more than a 10-percent holding, and potentially even less, of a non-financial firm in a financial firm. She emphasizes that her bill aims to provide diversity and options to American financial consumers, while simultaneously being conscious of consumer safeguards and promoting healthy competition.

The firms could own no more than 25 percent of a financial business smaller than themselves, but they could own up to 10 percent of a larger firm. The Roukema bill goes further than the Leach to control such ownership. Commercial companies could own up to 10 percent of a financial services firm, but no more than 5 percent of any subsidiary of the firm. This would more closely limit a bank, for instance, from being controlled by a commercial firm.

input: The debate is part of the continuing clashes between consumers and businesses demanding more secure communications, on one side, and an anxiety by law enforcement to maintain access to encrypted messages, on the other. Encryption scrambles messages, making them unreadable except to those who possess the proper key. The current restrictions, imposed in the early 1990s, only allow companies to export products with relatively weak 64-bit encryption, thwarting them from taking advantage of the stronger 128-bit encryption favored by most foreign nations.  Last year, President Clinton dramatically relaxed restrictions on the export of encryption but maintained a "dual use" system, which essentially requires companies to jump through some export hoops when they send products abroad using encryption.

Introducing PRO-CODE: Unlocking Enhanced Encryption Technology for Export

In the realm of secure communication, an evolution is underway to address the limitations imposed by current laws governing encryption exports. PRO-CODE emerges as a groundbreaking solution, equipping companies with the ability to export encryption technology furnished with keys up to 64-bits in length. By leveraging PRO-CODE, companies are equipped with enhanced encryption capabilities that transcend conventional boundaries. The updated encryption standard paves the way for more robust data protection, empowering businesses to safeguard sensitive information effectively. This breakthrough allows a seamless transition to heightened security measures without compromising compatibility or operational efficiency.

Built upon extensive research and global collaboration, PRO-CODE aims to strike a balance between facilitating secure international communication and minimizing potential risks. The revolutionary shift from the 40-bit encryption limit to the more formidable 64-bit standard ensures that technological advancements do not become a hindrance to global business operations. It marks a significant stride towards harmonizing privacy standards worldwide, while enabling companies to stay at the forefront of encryption technology.

PRO-CODE offers a multifaceted approach to address the concerns surrounding encryption exports. Not only does it enhance the security of data transmission but it also instills confidence in businesses seeking to expand beyond borders. This technology opens doors to international markets, enables seamless collaboration, and fortifies privacy in an increasingly interconnected world.

In conclusion, PRO-CODE propels encryption technology into a new era by allowing companies to export encryption with powerful 64-bit keys. A step forward from the current 40-bit limitation, this groundbreaking solution empowers businesses to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of their data. By embracing PRO-CODE, companies can unlock the potential of secure international communication while mitigating risks, thereby propelling global business operations to new heights.

input: Goodlatte's bill would:  remove export bans on encryption products, allowing U.S. companies to freely export most products. require the National Institute of Standards and Technology to develop a flexible algorithm, or basic set of programming instructions, to be used for encryption. allow computer companies to incorporate their own algorithms, such as those used by Netscape. exempt most Internet-based companies from any reporting requirements to the government about sales of encryption products. allow software companies to share protected encryption source code with foreign subsidiaries.
Revise this with your best effort:
Goodlatte's proposed bill encompasses several significant measures. Firstly, it aims to eliminate export bans on encryption products, enabling American companies to freely distribute a wide range of products internationally. Additionally, the bill mandates the National Institute of Standards and Technology to devise a versatile algorithm, serving as a foundational set of instructions for encryption processes. This provision also permits computer companies to integrate their unique algorithms, including those utilized by Netscape.

Moreover, the bill exempts the majority of internet-based firms from compulsory reporting obligations to the government regarding the sale of encryption products. This move acknowledges the importance of fostering privacy and business autonomy in the digital realm. Additionally, software companies are granted the ability to share protected encryption source code with their foreign subsidiaries, fostering collaboration and innovation on a global scale.

Firstly, it would eliminate export bans on encryption products, granting U.S. companies the freedom to export a wide range of products without restrictions. This move not only promotes international trade, but also showcases the capabilities of American encryption technology.

Secondly, the bill mandates the National Institute of Standards and Technology to develop a flexible algorithm - a set of programming instructions - to serve as a foundation for encryption. This ensures that encryption methods are consistently updated and adaptable to evolving challenges.

Furthermore, the bill allows computer companies to incorporate their own algorithms, like the ones utilized by Netscape, enhancing innovation and competition within the encryption sector.

To foster a conducive business environment, the bill proposes exempting most Internet-based companies from reporting requirements to the government regarding their sales of encryption products. This empowers these companies to operate with greater autonomy and efficiency.

Finally, the bill grants software companies the ability to share protected encryption source code with their foreign subsidiaries. This provision encourages collaboration and knowledge sharing while maintaining proper safeguards to protect sensitive information.

Overall, Goodlatte's bill offers a comprehensive approach to modernizing encryption regulations, promoting innovation, streamlining business operations, and strengthening the United States' presence in the global encryption market.

input: The Comptroller of the Currency last Wednesday indicated it may preempt and override a Rhode Island law that bankers say discriminates against them in favor of other insurance sellers. The Rhode Island measure, which takes effect April 1, requires companies selling insurance to register with the state, pay a fee and adhere to certain training and consumer disclosure rules. But it also requires that bank personnel involved exclusively in banking activities, such as loan origination, must not sell insurance. Insurance sold by banks must be separate from any banking activities, the measure said.  The Comptroller's Office said that the Rhode Island law may interfere with national banks' ability to offer insurance products. It asked for public comment and can pre-empt the state law if it is found to be unduly burdensome.

input: In a speech to a congressional joint committee examining amendments to federal financial laws, Greenspan likened the development of new financial products and markets to the birth of nuclear power, which sparked a "craze of nuclear optimism" as energy experts sought to solve global energy needs.  "Years later, the emphasis shifted," he said. "The realization that the chain reaction of nuclear fission, while a source of enormous potential for good, also carried with it sever risks and possible catastrophe." That is analogous to the current state of financial markets, he said. "As the dynamic growth and competitive environment in the complex of financial markets continue, sometimes beyond our understanding, the potential for enhanced economic efficiency is enormous," he said. "But let us not forget that the stability of marketplace operations remains equally important. There can be no doubt that systemic risks will continue to accompany many of the activities occurring in mature markets for some time to come."
Revise this with your best effort:
During a speech delivered to a congressional joint committee tasked with reviewing modifications to federal financial laws, Greenspan astutely drew a parallel between the emergence of novel financial products and markets and the advent of nuclear power. He likened it to the period of "nuclear optimism" that began when energy experts sought to provide solutions for global energy requirements. However, he highlighted a shift in focus that occurred over time, where the recognition of the potential hazard and catastrophic risks associated with nuclear fission became apparent.

In a similar vein, Greenspan asserted that the current status of financial markets aligns with this analogy. Acknowledging the continuous growth and competitive nature of these intricate market systems, he emphasized that at times they extend beyond our comprehension. Undeniably, the potential for heightened economic efficiency in this environment is immense. Nevertheless, he cautioned against neglecting the importance of maintaining stability within marketplace operations.

Greenspan draw attention to the sobering reality that systemic risks will persist alongside the activities taking place in well-established markets for the foreseeable future. In essence, he urged the committee to bear in mind that although the pursuit of enhanced economic prosperity is crucial, it must not overshadow the necessity to safeguard the stability of the market as a whole.

input: "The challenge of modern financial regulation is to modernise the regulatory system without compromising the safety and soundness of the system," Greenspan said.  Greenspan warned, however, that while "for the vast majority of firms, competition has provided an adequate shield against serious losses," not all financial disasters can be prevented. To guard against such disasters, he said, required "a concerted effort by the entire financial system to contain those relatively few losses that can become systemic."  Greenspan likened the role of financial regulators to the containment of a nuclear reaction. "In a financial system, the containment barrier is the set of regulations that have evolved over the years."

He emphasized the necessity for the entire financial industry to work together in order to prevent the few losses that could have systemic implications. input: "It is important to remember that the impetus to contain this kind of risk is not sought in the pursuit of some utopian concept of markets devoid of all government oversight," Greenspan said. "The task of regulations is to minimize the probability of systemic problems and, should they arise, to contain them to an extent that spillovers to the general economy are minimized or avoided," he said.  Greenspan, who has repeatedly emphasized the need for Congress to modernise financial laws, used a nuclear physics analogy to describe the challenge of avoiding catastrophic economic markets. "That cataclysmic interaction, which can be compared to the chain reaction of nuclear physics, has been the preferred method of warfare of the twentieth century and can be the entrance to economic failure," he said.

input: Greenspan Warns Against Too Much Regulation  Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan warned against excessive regulations on some forms of derivatives trading by sophisticated institutional investors.  In a speech at a Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta conference, Greenspan warned that tight regulations on the trading of derivatives, financial instruments whose value is based on the value of something else such as a commodity, stock or currency price, could interfere with the efficient workings of financial markets.
Revise this with your best effort: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan delivered a cautionary message, urging against the imposition of excessive regulations on certain derivative trading activities conducted by sophisticated institutional investors. He emphasized that such measures could disrupt the smooth functioning of financial markets, thus advocating for a more balanced approach.

input: The lawsuit, which pits banks against credit unions, is being followed closely in the banking industry and by consumer groups, which argue that credit unions provide lower-cost services than do banks.  At issue is whether the National Credit Union Administration (NCUA), which regulates federal credit unions, had the authority to allow credit unions to join together members from distinct groups into "multi-group" unions.  Banks have argued that the law Congress originally passed creating credit unions only allowed a single group of people to band together in a credit union. To permit multi-group credit unions was to let them compete unfairly in the banking industry, the banks stated.  But in its appeal to the Supreme Court, the Justice Department argued that multi-group credit unions actually encourage competition among banks by providing a banking alternative for those not easily served by banks.

Banks claim that the original legislation only allowed a single group to form a credit union, arguing that multi-group unions unfairly compete in the banking industry. However, the Justice Department, in its appeal to the Supreme Court, asserts that multi-group credit unions actually foster competition by providing a banking alternative for underserved individuals who face difficulty accessing traditional banking services.

input: Encryption products are essential tools for protecting consumer data, improving security, and facilitating commerce around the world. The new rule is intended to ensure they are not misused by foreign governments or malicious actors. It will require companies to acquire a license before exporting items that contain certain types of encryption technology. These include encryption products that have been modified to reduce their security thresholds; products with relatively weak encryption standards; and products whose primary purpose is to obscure data trails. Companies would also be required to obtain licenses for mass market products targeting foreign customers.

The introduction of a new regulation aims to prevent their misuse by foreign governments or malicious entities. These encompass modified encryption products that compromise their security thresholds, products utilizing relatively weaker encryption standards, and those primarily designed to obfuscate data trails. Additionally, licenses will also be necessary for mass market products intended for foreign consumers.

input: The case, Manhattan Regional Agency LLC v. United States Commodity Futures Trading Commission, was brought by a New York-based financial services company that had been accused by the CFTC of illegally trading in foreign currencies. The company, which argued that the CFTC had overstepped its authority, challenged the agency's jurisdiction, prompting the Supreme Court to take up the case. The court ultimately decided the case on two questions: does the CFTC have the jurisdiction to regulate foreign currency transactions; and if so, was the CFTC's enforcement of the law in this case appropriate?

United States Commodity Futures Trading Commission involved a New York financial services company accused by the CFTC of engaging in illegal trading of foreign currencies. Asserting that the CFTC had exceeded its authority, the company challenged the agency's jurisdiction, leading to the Supreme Court's involvement. The court specifically addressed two pivotal questions: whether the CFTC possesses the authority to regulate foreign currency transactions, and if so, whether its enforcement actions were appropriate in this particular case.

input: Writing for the majority, Justice Brett Kavanaugh noted that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission could enforce its authority in cases where there was a "direct and significant connection" between the transaction and US markets or participants. But he added that in most cases, the CFTC lacked the authority to police foreign currency trades conducted outside the US.

However, Justice Kavanaugh also acknowledged that, in the majority of instances, the CFTC lacks the necessary authority to regulate foreign currency trades executed beyond the borders of the United States.

input: According to Professor Matthew Smith of the University of Michigan, one of the authors of the study, the challenge is twofold. "Many users don't feel they need to switch from their current providers," Smith said, "while others simply don't know what other online services are available." To address this challenge, online businesses need to focus on marketing and product differentiation.
